name: ObservationDefinition
description: Set of definitional characteristics for a kind of observation or measurement produced or consumed by an orderable health care service.

properties.name: ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: Set of definitional characteristics for a kind of observation or measurement produced or consumed by an orderable health care service.
properties.comment: An instance of this resource informs the consumer of a health-related service (such as a lab diagnostic test or panel) about how the observations used or produced by this service will look like.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
properties.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

properties.name: meta
properties.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

properties.name: implicitRules
properties.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
properties.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
properties.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

properties.name: language
properties.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
properties.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

properties.name: text
properties.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
properties.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
properties.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

properties.name: contained
properties.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
properties.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

properties.name: publisher
properties.short: The name of the individual or organization that published the ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the ObservationDefinition. May also allow for contact.

properties.name: category
properties.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation.
properties.comment: This element allows various categorization schemes based on the ownerâ€™s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used for one instance of ObservationDefinition. The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.

properties.name: code
properties.definition: Describes what will be observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "name".

properties.name: identifier
properties.short: Business identifier for this ObservationDefinition instance
properties.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this ObservationDefinition artifact.

properties.name: permittedDataType
properties.short: Quantity | CodeableConcept | string | boolean | integer | Range | Ratio | SampledData | time | dateTime | Period
properties.definition: The data types allowed for the value element of the instance observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: multipleResultsAllowed
properties.definition: Multiple results allowed for observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.
properties.comment: An example of observation allowing multiple results is "bacteria identified by culture". Conversely, the measurement of a potassium level allows a single result.

properties.name: method
properties.short: Method used to produce the observation
properties.definition: The method or technique used to perform the observation.
properties.comment: Only used if not implicit in observation code.

properties.name: preferredReportName
properties.definition: The preferred name to be used when reporting the results of observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: quantitativeDetails
properties.definition: Characteristics for quantitative results of this observation.

properties.name: customaryUnit
properties.definition: Customary unit used to report quantitative results of observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: unit
properties.definition: SI unit used to report quantitative results of observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: conversionFactor
properties.short: SI to Customary unit conversion factor
properties.definition: Factor for converting value expressed with SI unit to value expressed with customary unit.

properties.name: decimalPrecision
properties.short: Decimal precision of observation quantitative results
properties.definition: Number of digits after decimal separator when the results of such observations are of type Quantity.

properties.name: qualifiedInterval
properties.short: Qualified range for continuous and ordinal observation results
properties.definition: Multiple  ranges of results qualified by different contexts for ordinal or continuous observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: category
properties.definition: The category of interval of values for continuous or ordinal observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: range
properties.short: The interval itself, for continuous or ordinal observations
properties.definition: The low and high values determining the interval. There may be only one of the two.

properties.name: context
properties.definition: Codes to indicate the health context the range applies to. For example, the normal or therapeutic range.

properties.name: appliesTo
properties.definition: Codes to indicate the target population this reference range applies to.
properties.comment: If this element is not present then the global population is assumed.

properties.name: gender
properties.definition: Sex of the population the range applies to.

properties.name: age
properties.definition: The age at which this reference range is applicable. This is a neonatal age (e.g. number of weeks at term) if the meaning says so.
properties.comment: Some analytes vary greatly over age.

properties.name: gestationalAge
properties.short: Applicable gestational age range, if relevant
properties.definition: The gestational age to which this reference range is applicable, in the context of pregnancy.

properties.name: condition
properties.short: Condition associated with the reference range
properties.definition: Text based condition for which the reference range is valid.

properties.name: validCodedValueSet
properties.short: Value set of valid coded values for the observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: The set of valid coded results for the observations  conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: normalCodedValueSet
properties.short: Value set of normal coded values for the observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: The set of normal coded results for the observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: abnormalCodedValueSet
properties.short: Value set of abnormal coded values for the observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: The set of abnormal coded results for the observation conforming to this ObservationDefinition.

properties.name: criticalCodedValueSet
properties.short: Value set of critical coded values for the observations conforming to this ObservationDefinition
properties.definition: The set of critical coded results for the observation conforming to this ObservationDefinition.
